docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''In Bid for Better Hospital Care, Heart Surgery With a Warranty'' (''Health Plans'' series, front page, May 17): I applaud Geisinger Health System's ProvenCare approach to narrowing the practice variation in providing medical care.
docs.abstract: Three letters respond to May 17 article on Geisinger Health System, which is offering guarantees of its medical care; Dr Pankaj Gupta applauds Geisinger's approach to 'narrowing practice variation' in providing medical care; Seth Trueger says Geisinger's warranty for surgery is commendable; Dr Michael Marek relates funny conversation he had about guaranteeing one's work

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Mammograms in Decline'' (editorial, May 15): While mammography screenings may have declined across the country, New York City's public hospitals have continued to meet a growing demand.
docs.abstract: Letter from Alan D Aviles, president of New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, comments on May 15 editorial citing National Cancer Institute report finding that there is small but significant decline in women scheduling annual mammograms; says new national data underscores need to fend off complacency even as New York City hospitals reach record screening numbers

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S spring: time to plant perennials, clean closets -- and call the microbial inspector. What does spring cleaning mean in the age of green? For many of us, it means fear. Homeowners whose grandparents beat rugs and washed windows worry about more than dirt. So what if the baseboards are dusty? The lead in the paint could be lowering your toddler's future SAT scores. The air may be fragrant with the season's first blooms, but that doesn't make you safe from colorless, odorless gases like radon and carbon monoxide. And, by the way, you're sneezing. Is it a cold, or is it mold?

headline.main: What's Furry and Thirsty and Loves the Dark?

docs.abstract: Article on household mold problems and mold detection and remediation, which has become big business in New York metropolitan area; experts comment on which types of mold are innocuous or more worrisome and what is done to eradicate them; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: FINISHING my lunch at an open-air restaurant in downtown Bangkok, I felt slightly queasy. But by the time the taxi arrived back at my hotel, sweat was pouring out of my armpits, the folds of my stomach, even my shins, and my leg joints buckled as if a diamond-tipped drill was boring into them. As I got out of the taxi, I collapsed onto the street. The taxi driver shoved me back into his cab, and we wove our way through the city's infamous traffic to Bumrungrad International, a hospital near my hotel. I barely made it to the emergency room before I passed out. When I woke and remembered what had happened, part of me wanted to bolt from my E.R. bed. I knew very little about Thai medical facilities, and recalled a clinic I'd seen in neighboring Myanmar, where patients had to bring their own linens, needles and even bandages to the hospital.

headline.main: Sometimes, Sightseeing Is a Look at Your X-Rays

docs.abstract: Joshua Kurlantzick travel article on medical tourism at time when spending on health care in America has topped $2 trillion; aging baby boomers, those without insurance, insurers and smaller employers are looking at overseas care as alternative to costly treatments, even for complex procedures; drawing (M)
